short: If something is prejudicial towards a particular point of view, you can call it partisan. You'll often hear about partisan politics in the U.S. ā since politicians seem to be completely devoted to the agendas of their own parties.
long: Partisan can be used to describe rabid supporters of any person or activity. In American English, however, it is most often used to refer to politics and the American two-party system of Democrats and Republicans. A bill introduced may have partisan support from the party that introduced the bill, or ā more rarely it seems to American voters ā the bill may even have bipartisan support. The prefix bi is added to show the support from both parties.
